key_risks: High subscription costs limiting access to knowledge, particularly in developing countries
Intense competition from other academic publishers and disruptive technologies
Operational and financial challenges due to the COVID-19 pandemic
controversies: Criticism over high subscription costs and limited access to academic journals
Recent board resignations raising governance concerns
social_issues: Concerns about equitable access to Wiley's resources globally
governance_issues: Recent resignations of board members George D. Bell and Beth A. Birnbaum

sources.title: John Wiley & Sons, Inc. -- Company History
sources.snippet: 1875: The company adopts the name John Wiley & Sons after John Wiley's son William Halsted Wiley comes onboard; W.H. Wiley is instrumental in the company's move into textbooks and science and technology publishing. 1904: The company is incorporated as John Wiley & Sons, Inc. 1959: The first overseas subsidiary is established in the United Kingdom.
